page.title: 03Buildings, Faceby
page.content: {Farmhouses}built of local freestone reflect the area's vernacular pattern. Many have been modernised, and grants from the local authority have enabled farmers and householders to re-roof, new pantiles adding colour to the landscape. At Mill Farm the original manorial mill is now extra living space. There are few unsightly sheds on farms, but some existing buildings have been converted to stabling. Three farms still retain the now obsolete horse-wheel shed with a shaped roof built on the threshing barn.{Faceby {Manor,}built 1880-90, now converted into two houses, and{Faceby Vicarage, now a private residence, are the only houses of size.{Faceby Church,}rebuilt in 1874, retains a Norman arch with zigzag and carved hood over the south doorway.{Whorlton Church and Castle} are Grade-I listed buildings.
